review_title: Good work-life balance, passionate people, but problems with racism
pros: The organization values its employees' work-life balance, co-workers are passionate about the mission, low turnover means that there's strong institutional memory, and the organization does important and impactful work for psychology.
cons: Pay is low and there are few opportunities for career advancement/training compared to other employers in the DC area and the health insurance is an HMO so you have limited choice when trying to find doctors. Co-workers who are people of color have also told me that they've experienced racism and harassment that the organization refused to respond to appropriately when it was reported.

pros: Flexible work. Telework. Work/life balance. Prioritize mental health and employee wellness.
cons: No annual cost of living raises. No paths for advancement. Limited paid parenting leave.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fairfax, VA
pros: Coworkers worked as a team
cons: Pay is below standards for todays economy

job_title: Multimedia Graphic Designer in Washington, DC
pros: APA has a great culture and community that continues to endure in my network many years after leaving to start my own business.
cons: It's hard to think of cons, APA is highly focused on the recognition and well-being of staff.

pros: The work is benefiting a great mission, the key customers were great, the colleagues were helpful and I made some life long friends.
cons: Unfortunately I heard from a coworker too late that I should have recorded any and all any meetings that a woman in library/higher ed management was in from current (and recently previous) employees, with a few employees in an adjacent department saying their director told them to never have a 1:1 with her alone. She’s known to twist words and make some pretty extreme ungrounded allegations, especially around culture and race. Kind of funny when she is a “mental health advocate”. The amount of support and colleagues reaching out after telling them what happened was almost sad, because they could relate and have heard similar stories. A few of them have said this solidified their job search to leave. Tensions seem to be running high for a while now within the higher education department, even before this incident happened with me. Employees have moved to other positions in a different department, or quit altogether, to not have to deal with issues with her. I hope me speaking about this will prevent this from happening to anyone else in the future. A bummer to the current employees and the department as a whole to having to “watch their back” with her. One bad apple really can ruin things.

job_title: Director, Government Relations in Washington, DC
pros: Great place to work. Strong leadership
cons: Repetitive workplace and struggle with new visions

pros: The benefits are ok. I had to put something here. Fully remote.
cons: The work environment does not reflect APA’s values that they’re always putting out for others to see. It’s a constant fight between departments creating an incredibly toxic and hostile environment. My mental health has worsened over the years working for APA. There is no room for growth/career advancement. Raises only happen following major layoffs.

job_title: Manager, Program Management in Washington, DC
pros: Great work life balance and benefits.
cons: Seems very siloed and it's difficult to move up in some offices.

review_title: Reevaluate leadership in higher ed / library
pros: Met some great life long colleagues and some of the hardest working people I’ve met
cons: The management of higher education (formally only library) is toxic and creates a hostile work environment. I can confirm there are a few of us searching for new opportunities since this department is underneath her, with other people leaving or moving departments specifically because of her. I’ve been told to record any meetings with her and not have a 1:1 alone with her. I would not recommend working here in this department if you want to enjoy your job and feel supported by management.

pros: APA understands that staff are humans first and employees after. They take the research findings around employee mental health and apply when able (remote work, mental health days). I feel supported, but not micromanaged!
cons: Less PTO time than some places, however you get a bank of it from Day 1 to borrow against for your first 6 months, then accrual begins.

pros: The communications team is some of the best and brightest people I’ve ever worked with. Strong leadership from our chief and frequent collaboration across teams. Supportive, positive, energetic environment. Interesting work that is incredibly meaningful. Continued remote work environment which makes many people happy.
cons: There are remnants of past struggled with a 5-year ago reorg. It takes a long time to get to know the full scope of the organization and its many divisions and departments. Internal politics must be navigated with care.

pros: Excellent work culture, good environment and friendly people
cons: Little room for career growth

pros: Meaningful work, good career advancement opportunities
cons: Over-emphasize on quantification of impact; poor communication between leadership and staff

pros: Great benefits and a kind community.
cons: Poor cross-departmental communication between Directorates.

pros: Great, dedicated, educated people; good mission; telework, good benefits
cons: low salary; not a whole lot of advancement opportunities

review_title: Can't find much good to say here, even in 2022
pros:
Benefits are good
2% 401K for everyone (whether you contribute or not)
Up to 5% 401K match
cons:
Poor wages for most except the Heads and Chiefs, who get six-figure bonuses while those at lower levels don't even get enough wages/raises to cover cost of living or inflation.
Outwardly makes statements about it's commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion when it comes to psychological science but doesn't value it within the association and with its employees.
APA's culture doesn't value the voices of its employees
Even though many of the great employees have or will be leaving, the association doesn't see that as sign to make changes

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits. Colleagues good to work with..
cons: Upper Executive management was not understanding of lower level needs.

pros: deal with big data will learn you a lot.
cons: nothing needs improvement for me.

review_title: Their values do not align with their functionality
pros: I have no pros to provide
cons: APA was the most toxic and traumatic, work experience of my life. Avoid working here at all costs.

pros: Still the best company I have worked for. No stress
cons: I'm not there working anymore

pros: Flexibility and room for professional growth.
cons: Working in the city is a tough commute.

pros: APA genuinely cares about making a positive impact in society and creating a culture that respects the mental health of its employees.
cons: APA is evolving, but not all parts of APA are eager to be part of the evolution. Some within APA are given a remarkable degree of latitude to dig in their heels. APA is not a place where it is easy to be promoted quickly. Depending on your other career options, you may need to leave money on the table to work at APA.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: salary was great during my time
cons: HR is lack luster at best

pros: The association offers great benefits.
cons: Restructuring was a problem at the association.

pros: Flexible work schedules, supportive of remote work.
cons: The executive leadership team isolates themselves from the rest of the organization, leading to ineffective communication (no flow either way) and no transparency. Jobs are ill-defined and seem to be entirely "other duties as assigned." Staff have to wait until the executives decide on a course of action and then have to quickly complete the job under the pressure of little time and guidance. Unsatisfying and unrewarding place to work.

pros: 1 - decent benefits, great mental health care reimbursement. 2 - Average compensation for a non-profit. 3 - good work schedule and space flexibilty - can be fully remote or partially/fully in-office in an incredible location right next to Union Station. 4 - a fantastic COVID response. Seriously, what a great job senior leadership did! In my cons, I'll talk a lot about the APA's seeming inability to actually implement change in an organized, decisive way, but the COVID response is an exception to that and something they got absolutely right. I felt safe, heard, and supported as we all made the switch to virtual, and I think I can safely say the same of all my colleagues. I had been advocating for several years for APA to move to a more updated and flexible working environment, and felt like APA would always be stuck in a 1992 business model, but leadership really and truly stepped up during the pandemic and knocked it out of the park.
cons: 1 - the organization has been undergoing change for the last 5 years, but none of the top leadership is clear with employees what the end goal is. We can tell it's changing, and it seems positive, maybe? But instead of saying "Here's where we're at, here's our goal, here's how we plan to make it happen, and here's the timeline," management just kinda says "Hey, change this one thing you do. We don't know how, figure it out." We've been in a particularly unsettled state for the last two years (and strangely, I don't think its pandemic related, but more "vision for the association" related), and it's evident in the vast number of senior leaders that APA is bleeding away. 2 - the right hand has no idea what the left is doing because there are pretty much no common practices that apply organization wide. Every directorate has different policies, and every team within every directorate has different policies. It means that workloads are nowhere near comparable from team to team and it only enhances the siloing issue. 3 - Speaking of that siloing issue, everyone seems to recognize it, leadership calls for tearing it down, but noone seems actually willing to do the work in a sensible way. Instead of setting concrete ways to decrease the siloing, leadership seems to be of the mind that they can just create positions that directly report to multiple different bosses in multiple different directorates and teams. There is a reason that successful organizations have clear reporting structures that, no matter how flat, do not typically include asking employees to report to more than one manager. It's unfair to the employees put in that situation, and unfair to their coworkers who are stuck vying for time when their colleague can "switch" to working on their side of the house. Not to mention it causes an unbelievable amount of tension between managers who are desperately trying to plan and manage projects and available manpower.

pros: Great benefits, flexible schedules, supportive teams available
cons: No vertical mobility, lack of varying position titles, raises are rare

pros: Nothing is worth working for this company
cons: Working for a monster. The most psychotic workplace in Australia.

pros: Provides opportunities for learning and supports employee health, great for those who love the profession and science of psychology and like being connected to knowledge and experts, many ways to utilize psychology for public good
cons: Internal career advancement can be difficult, annual salary increases are small, large gaps in pay between top executives and other workers, complicated structure of volunteer leadership

pros: Great people, valuable work, and competitive salary
cons: Sometimes working with other parts of the organization was difficult

pros: Nice people and good training
cons: There were honestly no cons

pros: Mental health, benefits, nice culture
cons: Bureaucracy, slow to change and adapt

pros: Good work life balance and mental health self care
cons: Average pay, vertical upward movement biased towards psychologists

pros: The team work is great
cons: Their compensation package was not good enough

pros: Good working space and environment for learning new things
cons: Freshers might feel little pressure

pros: nothing good noted from employee perspective
cons:
no opportunity for advancement
minimal benefit
absence of continuation of care for patients

pros: Makes a lot of effort to take care of its employees both with pay and life-work balance.
cons: Some antiquated processes and thinking, but these seem to be improving.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: PTO, and work day ended at 4:30pm
cons: Took too long to get anything done. Hard to build rapport with colleagues.

pros:
Interesting work
Great Life/work balance
Good Salary
cons:
Difficult to do new things
Resistant to change

pros:
-Great PTO
-Right next to the metro
-Competitive pay (depends on the department you are in though)
-Training opportunities available
-Ability to work from home
cons:
The biggest con overall is the culture at APA. The departments are very siloed, which can make work difficult to get done depending on the project. Also, there is this unwillingness to change. I do think the organization is trying to move in the right direction, but old and outdated values are in the way of progress.

The people that have been at the organization for a long time tend to take over projects and roles they aren't qualified for. It's frustrating when you are trying to do the job you were hired for and other people (with no expertise on the matter) take over.

pros:
-places high importance on the employee's well-being
-great office location in the District of Columbia
-dedicated staff working within the departments 
-the organization is socially conscious and takes the current climate of affairs into account when leading their employees
cons: I don't have a lot of cons for this organization because the things that matter, they address. Allowing employees to continue remote work protected us all from the Delta variant. Throughout the entire pandemic they have asked for employee feedback and used it to make decisions that impact us all. When everything is really considered, it's hard to find a con with APA.

pros: Nice to work here with others.
cons: Not nice to work with boss

pros: Dedicated long term association staff
cons: Internal politica can be fatal.

pros: Good working place. Nice place.
cons: Nothing at the moment to say.

pros: - modest salary with annual reviews
cons: - micro management at every level

job_title: Special Projects Manager in Washington, DC
pros: APA has a lot of good points - decent pay, decent hours, decent benefits are the top three. Not the best in the area, but definitely near the top of the nonprofit scale. Their handling of COVID was prompt, appropriate and made me feel safe and heard. Historically, APA has been slow to adapt to modern communication and work methods, but the executive team truly stepped it up in response to COVID.
cons: Look, a person can be a really, really great psychologist, researcher, or neuroscientist and still be an absolutely terrible program manager. Nonprofit and association professional training, degrees, and certifications exist for a reason, and being a passionate, effective advocate for psychology issues or civil rights does not always, or even often, translate into to stellar management skills. It's great to employ psychologists at the APA, but every manager and director doesn't need to be, and shouldn't be, always only a PhD/PsyD. The organization desperately needs more, well, organization and modernization. So many Directors and Senior Directors here are hopelessly disorganized, overwhelmed, and less effective than they could be if they had better management, workflow, and organizational skills. Unfortunately, when you get a bunch of psychologists together, you often end up talking about a dozen different potential work models, but never sticking with one and creating solid operating protocols. What's worse, you get every department using a different model, no solid connections between departments, and no cohesive way to complete simple, interdepartmental processes.

pros: APA does a lot of good work. Lots of support to employees during pandemic. Great benefits, especially paid time off, holidays, 401K and lots of health and wellness perks. Flexible schedules too. Fantastic CEO who communicates with employees.
cons: Large, complicated governance structure that holds back the association from being nimble. It creates unnecessary work and stress for a lot of staff.

pros: Great medical benefits, including mental health.
cons: Too many meetings, not enough action.

pros: Great coworkers and some management, a lot of great activities geared toward employee moral (pre covid), great benefits, right by Union Station
cons: Lower level employees are underpaid

pros: Great worklife balance, benefits, and workplace wellness
cons: Currently very understaffed and some manager's can be better than others in terms of promoting worklife balance

pros:
great office location and nice building
good pay and benefits
good people, friendly staff

pros: It is good company that i have been

pros: good job to have good people

job_title: Data Platform Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Great location, interesting work, good benefits
cons: Bureaucracy, poor management, little room for growth

pros: Management tends to be somewhat flexible
cons: Low salaries for everyone except high level executives

pros: APA is a great place to work in terms of providing an excellent work/life balance and very good benefits including onsite gyms, generous PTO and classes such as lunchtime yoga and pilates. I do get the feeling that the executive office genuinely wants to provide a good environment for it's employees.
cons: The cons are more to do with actual opportunities. Though this will greatly vary between offices since many operate autonomously. There is no real trajectory for advancement, just general categories of the Director level, the middle level and the assistant level. In many cases, getting to the Director level requires a PhD and specialized knowledge in an area of psychology, so it's not likely that someone who came to APA starting at the assistant level would reach the Director level (unless the took some years off to go back to school and get their PhD). I think that for many people coming in at the assistant or middle levels who are serious about their careers would likely find APA as more of a good base point. A place to work for a couple years and move on. The upside is that the salaries aren't bad, the benefits are great and all in all it's not a particularly stressful environment so it's ideal for people who aren't 100% career focused. This is a great place to work if you have a family and outside interests that you want to pursue. If you're the Type-A go-getter, wants to always finish ahead, competitive type, you'll probably get bored after awhile.

review_title: Horrible Bosses.... It's not just a movie title...
pros: The Paid TIme Off is incredible.
cons: There are many.... too many to count or address in the limited space that I have here to experess myself. If you accept a job at the APA, be expected to have no voice or ability to express concern for things that you have prior experience doing or have had success with in your other roles. The APA holds the notion that even though you have had many years of successful experience prior to being hired, the APA knows best - and will fundamentally crush your soul. Aside from that, forget about asking anyone for advice or additional training. It is not provided. You are given a basic overview of the role, told a few things and expected to immediately start closing business - for products that have not been completely developed.... This was my experience and may have changed, but I doubt it. Oh, and don't bother to speak with Human Resources about any of the issues that you may have, as they are completely and utterly inept.

pros: Excellent company to work for
cons: Not the best at doing some rooms

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: The company is really big on work life balance which is a big plus.
cons: The culture at APA is a big issue.

pros:
-Kind and talented people
-Company-wide mindset of caring about employee well-being (financial, mental, and career)
-Upper management consistently recognizes achievements and thanks employees; encourages this behavior in all
-Clear ways to advance
-Depending on your team/department, you can make a big difference with new ideas
-Lots of holidays, options to telework, and flexible hours, and managers who actually encourage using them!
-Competitive pay for a nonprofit
-Genuinely works to keep employees happy and productive
-Very metro-friendly

Coming to APA as a new parent, I was blown away by how accommodating they are! There was never any question of my value as an employee or my ability to be a productive team member. Everyone wanted me to be able to work at APA in whatever form that had to take. A true rarity and so very appreciated.
cons:
-Departments are very silo’d; rarely do ideas cross-pollinate
-Multiple levels of committees and management can stall projects or new ideas
-Entrenched departmental habits are almost impossible to break, even if they could be improved
-Large organization means that decisions are often made without consulting expert teams
-Not always clear who to talk to about policies, procedures, or best practices
-Dress code is old fashioned

pros: Flexibility in working schedule.  Very nice people and family like culture here.  Smaller size company so you get to learn more things and gain more experiences.  There are less layer of bureaucracies.  Staff stay here for long time probably because the working environment is static and not too many changes over the years.  It provides great comfort zone for those who don't like change.  Work and life balance is good for some.
cons: The Cons are just the flip sides of the Pros above.  It does not have proper processes to support the growth.  The few layers of bureacracies that exist may have come from few people who have been there for a long time which is ver strong and will stay there for awhile.  There are not too many emphasis in training for people managers. So some people managers may not know how to be effective managers and to value subordinates and empower them to succeed.  Work and life balance is good for some and not too god for others depending on your responsibilities.  This might be why new people do not stay too long and not enough to influence change on the old culture.

review_title: Old school, Various Departmental flavors and no consistency but it maybe in the process to change
pros: In some aspect, it is quicker to make decision and adopt new technology for efficiency that are owned by newer leaders came from more progressive background. Case by case Flexibility but you have to proof yourselves before enjoy some flexibility .. and this not across board either
cons: My assumption that APA is full of exemplary leaders with high emotional intelligence is totally wrong. They are all over the map. Managers are mostly from old school and not properly trained to manage people. Leaders and managers I know do not know how to inspire and motivate their team. All these negativities maybe due to my high expectation of APA leaders to walk the talk and it is just very disappointing. On the other hand, APA thinks that psychology and psychologist are superior than the rest of the world. Very high turn over in some department and might be due to lower salary and lack of leadership inspiration. Hopeful that these might change as APA is financially is just OK and it may not grow well without changing things

review_title: A Good Company Whose Culture May Be Changing for the Worse
pros: The association tries to create a work-life balance. It also tries to create a healthy workplace. Employees have the chance to take meditation classes and yoga. There also is a nap room. The health benefits are good, the mental health benefits are great--80 percent covered no limit on visits. Pay isn't so great. Andc. APA does encourage growth within the company. However, promotions are not always accompanied by a pay raise. Overall, it's a liberal place to work--good place for someone who is gay or transgendered. There are gay and lesbian employees in high positions. It is also very accommodating for those with physical disabilities. Great vacation benefits, 2 percent contribution to 401K and then a match up to 4 percent. Overall it was a good place to work, but some seriously dysfunction areas of the association have not been dealt with.
cons: A good work culture that seems to be changing. Employees who are working with difficult management have virtually no place to go for help. Pay can be low.

review_title: Great place if you have your doctorate, otherwise, its only OK.
pros: Great co-workers (but this is highly dependent upon what directorate and/or office you are in). Competitive 401K benefit and competitive health benefits package.
cons: LOW salaries, very minimal room for advancement unless you have or will be receiving your doctoral degree. Even then, if it is not in the field of psychology, you will experience discrimination and psychology doctorates will receive a preference! The members tend to be ungrateful, rude, inept, and overwhelming at times (compared to other member association populations). During economic slump of 2008-2010, employees COL raises and other benefits were stripped away, while executives were exempt from this AND were even being offered incentive packages so "the best talent could be retained".

pros:
It really depends on which department you find yourself in. Some are pretty soul-crushing, whereas others seem to be full of sunshine and light. 

I find that there's a pretty good work-life balance. I feel comfortable leaving work at the office and taking PTO when I need it. APA offer pretty good benefits, especially the excellent PTO. There's lots of organization-wide activities if you're into that kind of thing.
cons:
The biggest problem is that there's no recourse for employees dealing with toxic managers. I know past employees have complained about the same person, who has remained in the same position for more than a decade while the terrible management behaviors go unchecked. So when I experience difficulties with this individual, I have nowhere to go. 

Though my initial salary was fairly competitive, the salary increases are laughably small. There's also little room for advancement in many departments, primarily due to things like toxic managers sticking around for too long and refusing to reward other employees.

review_title: APA Should Read its Own Research
pros: Excellent benefits and truly wonderful people. One can learn a lot here.
cons: Middle management in Publications & Databases! While the upper level managers seem competent, some of the  mid-level managers have a very rigid, authoritarian style. They seem to not trust their own team members, even very long-term employees with consistently proven records. Employees are treated like naughty children and shown in multiple ways that they are not valued and can easily be replaced. Huge disparity between the i/o psychology research conducted/disseminated by this organization and their own practices, a consistent source of "inside jokes" among employees. The former family-friendly telecommuting policy was recently reduced by 50%, creating real issues for caregivers and commuters who depend on telecommuting  to allow some degree of work-life balance. Such a shame--this organization used to be such a wonderful, progressive place to work! Stress is high. However, this varies greatly depending on the department, as there is little uniformity between units. Salaries are quite low.

job_title: Business Operations Assistant (Former Employee) in Washington, DC
pros:
I actually left the APA in 2004 (However, the above drop-down menu did not go back far enough).

The only "bright spot" was that their IT & technology staff (at that time), were fairly pleasant, cordial, & knowledgeable folks.
cons:
My impression of this organization (having spent 7-8 years working there) was basically...

Many of the management staff clearly climbed the "leadership ladder" (over a number of years) because more talented coworkers left the organization. It was clearly NOT because the managers generally possessed keen intellect, great leadership skills, or had any superior managerial aptitude. While I was there, a number of persons (whom I identified as fairly intelligent persons with good work ethic) got tired of the poor management, non-competitive pay, & lack of growth opportunities. Most of those persons LEFT.

review_title: Great benefits and people, terrible management and supervising
pros: Great benefits such as flexible with a work-life/ healthy lifestyle balance. Awesome $1 yoga pilates and other classes. A room to sleep if you are tired, gym use all day, fun activities with entire APA colleagues that are sponsored by building management. Over all its a good place to work, and with the exception of some supervisors.
cons: No bonuses, no commision, hard to get a raise, hard to find a job that doesnt require a PHD or a masters or a focus in Psychology.

review_title: Like any other professional association, equal amounts of pros & cons
pros:
1. Genuinely strong internal hiring practices
2. Excellent facilities and highly maintained work space
3. Slightly above average pay relative to the rest of DC
4. Generous work-life balance for senior management, not so much for other program staff
5. Convenient location to the Metro, beneficial for commuting staff
6. Highly competent, reliable IT/web content staff
cons:
1. Hard to retain highly qualified (and perhaps, better suited) temporary employees/interns or recruit new talent, due to their strong internal hiring practices.
2. Slow, slow work pace. Almost intentionally slow, though this depends on the directorate. 
3. Unfortunately, very little to no interaction or communication between inter-directorate offices. Is practically discouraged, unless you're senior management. Very likely you will never know the person working 2-3 offices or cubicles from you. It's not personal; it's just the office environment.

pros:
- A lot of ability to be creative in my role 
- Consistency and autonomy 
- Love my direct management 
- Coworkers are bright and driven
- GREAT benefits; 401k matching, dental, gym/shower in building (and another available in neighboring building), rooftop terrace area, massages available in the building, awesome location next to Union Station so near lots of food options and like a 1 min walk from metro
- Really like the direction the org is going; new CEO, new and innovative conferences and events 
- Everyone here is deeply passionate about the power of psychology and science to benefit society and improve people's lives
cons:
- Very silo-ed; departments work very separately from one another, but APA has acknowledged that and is taking active steps to address
- Things can move very slowly, and as such it can be frustrating at times to try to get anything done quickly

pros:
Salary
Paid Time Off
Health Insurance Benefits (expensive) 
The Mission of the APA
Convenient location of office in DC to Union Station 
Working Environment
cons: Middle to Upper Management is completely inept.  Constant changes in strategy without explanation. Extremely rigid school of thought by certain key stakeholders responsible for development of product. Inability of management to grasp sales cycle in new areas of concentration.

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
pros: The benefits are good. Like most places, your job satisfaction depends a lot on what department you are in and who your immediate supervisor is.
cons: The CEO and executive management are running this place to the ground. Way too many executive managers are eating up the budget with huge salaries. This year, we have a projected $12 million operating deficit. Last year, only a select few employees received a salary increase.  All of this is happening during very good economic times.  Some of the working environments are toxic because of unreasonable management demands and bullying. APA responds to these situation by offering classes on how to deal with difficult people and how to deal with stress.

review_title: Potential to be a great company...but...
pros: Under my manager I was able to grow and learn from this position (finance). The benefits are awesome - 5 weeks of vacation per year for new staff and other great benefits. Hours were also a plus - 9-5 straight through the week. I've worked only a few weekends, but only because of deadlines in the Finance department.
cons: Policies...policies...and more policies. The company is full of them and management follows the policies to the extreme at times. There isn't much flexibility in the work hours even though the same work can be done at different times. Trying to change policies for efficiency purposes will surely be met with resistance. Each department acts very independently from others and there is a lack of cohesion.

review_title: good if you're ready to settle
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at APA include: their PTO policy/accrual rate, the flexibility of working at home for some positions, a quiet room which can be used for relaxing, and a great location for easy metro access/food options.
cons: Some of the most egregious downsides of working at APA include: the lack of upward career opportunities, low pay, management that lacks the ability to motivate and lead their subordinates, and odd financial decisions made by the uppers that hinder or subvert organizational growth.

review_title: Pleasant workplace, inefficient and inflexible company
pros: Great benefits, particularly generous vacation time. Management, despite their challenges, genuinely seem to care about their employees and the psychological discipline and profession (though perhaps not as much as they care about their own advancement).  The company has a uniquely helpful and friendly HR department.
cons: It’s a heavily siloed and top-heavy organization. Recent management changes and infrequent executive-level communication can be a challenge despite attempts to improve. Business practices are outmoded and change is glacially slow. Governance system is cumbersome, overly political, and an encumbrance to effectively realizing organizational potential. It tries to be too many things to too many people and would benefit from refining and clarifying its mission and strategic priorities.

review_title: Benefits no longer outweigh the negatives
pros:
Some managers offer flexible schedules
Two gyms on site, plus weekly exercise classes
Convenient to red line/Capitol hill 
PTO and sick days combined, so extra vacation if you never get sick
Feels like you're working toward a noble and important mission
cons:
Pay is well below average for a non-profit, especially in DC.
Recognition of hard work is rare. Merit-based and cost of living wages are not guaranteed, and are meager when given. 
Huge, and very siloed organization, so no one ever knows what else is going on in the organization.
Limited upward mobility.
Major recent scandals have decreased morale.

pros: So many nice, friendly people. Good location across from Metro station. Flex schedules, wellness programs, onsite gym, awesome PTO benefit. Kaiser is conveniently nearby,
cons: Big shakeup in past few years, lots of organizational changes. Does not feel like a nonprofit anymore. Management pushing revenue and being a great business. Mission not valued anymore. Cuts to mission driven programs, budget and staff. Growth only in ITS. Why so many ITS staff necessary is unclear. APA is slow with lots of bureaucracy. Takes years to get some things done.

pros: Great mission, friendly colleagues, good benefits
cons: Floundering vision, little to no opportunities for upward growth. There is no clear mission for moving the organization forward. Staff are presented with lots of changes and little to no communication about how these changes came about or how they will improve the organization, leaving employees skeptical and unmotivated. Managers are inconsistent in how they recognize staff, giving the organization a feeling of being a bunch of siloes that have little impact on one another.  Upward growth potential is limited, which is not unusual in nonprofits, but is disappointing given APA's supposed focus on promoting a psychologically healthy workplace

review_title: A place where career trajectory goes to die...
pros: APA has a ton of perks: work from home, mostly kind coworkers, good insurance, 401k match, massages, work/life balance. It's a place that sends out 1,000 surveys to make sure they're "including your input" but generally does nothing with the information. If you have a family and want to leave at 5, this is a good place to settle into.
cons: Okay, so while APA has a ton of perks (mentioned above), it is also a environment where many of the employees are incompetent and in positions of power. They've literally been warming their seat for years and they know it. With so much institutional change happening, they're running scared and power grabbing. And when new, smart people come into the organization, they're asserting themselves aggressively to stake their claim. In addition to this, almost everyone in a high management position has a PhD which makes them very smart but also very inept to manage people. Last but not least, there is no way to move up in this organization. You can either take on a completely new role, one which makes no sense for your career or you can warm your seat. They give 2-3% annual raises which basically accounts for inflation in a city that is becoming so expensive it's unlivable. While no one (except C-suite people) make a lot of money, there are great disparities in pay. Lastly, HR is useless. Sorry HR, I've never had a positive experience and I am lucky if I get an email returned from you.

review_title: Not a place to work. Leadership is not transparent and go against their own workplace policies. Terrible culture.
pros: Used to be a great place to work. Had work/life balance and treated people the way it should given there business is human emotion. New management has created a toxic culture in my areas.
cons: No open dialogue or communication. Management is completely out of touch with the culture they are breeding. Laying off many long time employees that have dedicated much of their life to an orgainzation they loved but has turned their back on them.

pros: APA has very generous benefits, a well-educated work force, interesting work, flexible work schedules, and an open environment.
cons: APA pays a lot of attention to lip service and impression management.  Peel back the layers and you will find the ugliness.  There is little opportunity for career advancement, management is not culturally or racially diverse in some program areas, management  and staff lack the training, skills, knowledge, or motivation to work in a 21st century culturally-diverse environment, and there is a performance evaluation system that has no oversight that leads to inequitable annual merit increases.

review_title: Great employee benefits but not a lot of high achievers
pros:
• 100% of mental health care/therapy covered except for the $20 copay!  No matter what therapist you choose to see--it's covered. I can't stress how incredible this is, and I hope more employees are taking advantage of it. Please don't take this for granted bc this benefit does not exist elsewhere.
• They offer a lot of health promoting activities to employees during work hours that are either free (2 gyms), or cost just a dollar to attend (zoomba, meditation, yoga, pilates, and discounted massages)
• The organization pushes staff recognition; there are often events that promote sending notes to coworkers thanking them for a job well done. Cheesy?  Yes.  However, I can't deny feeling good when I get one of those from a coworker.  It's really taught me the importance of recognizing and acknowledging someone's hard work.
• Great professional development training courses offered on site during work hours.  
• Interesting Brown Bag seminars on topics related to psychology and health.
cons:
• I have been disappointed to discover that, while the organization stresses working the full 7.5 hour days, there are higher level staff that don't abide by this.  Most work the hours they should, but the few that don't make it difficult to work alongside with when you're putting in the hours and they aren't.
• DC attracts a lot of high achievers, but many of them aren't at APA.  People work, but they don't often reach for the stars, or put in that little extra to go above and beyond the call of duty.  For example, the organization is currently trying to push psychology's inclusion in the government's long term plan for integrative health care, which is GREAT and essential for the field of psychology, which has always gone unrecognized by medicine. In my opinion though, they aren't doing enough.  There is so much more they can do, so much potential, but they just aren't standing up and taking action in a big way.
• There is something about the members of this organization, that lends them to be really emotional, opinionated, and at times, unprofessional.  I think it boils down to the type of people who are attracted to this field, but I've often been surprised to read some inflammatory emails sent by a member through a professional listserve.

pros:
Competitive benefits
Great location
Interesting and impactful work
Work/life balance
cons:
Pay is not competitive
Psychology knowledge and subject matter expertise is no longer appreciated
Workplace bullying was rare a decade ago, but is pervasive now

review_title: This is a decent place to work
pros: The management makes an effort to accommodate employees in maintaining a work/life balance. The benefits package is very good (health care, including mental health, paid holidays and vacation/sick leave). Many employees have flexible work schedules. Salaries are okay. There are many wellness programs in place (exercise classes, meditation classes, an in-house gym) as well as some tuition reimbursement for accredited college courses.
cons: Pace of work can be slow; there are layers of bureaucracy to go through for changes such as work duties, new and internal hires. Not a lot of opportunities for career development, though there are some.

pros:
Great benefits, usually. This is one of the most benefits generous places that I've worked. There's a contribution to your 401k, even if you contribute nothing. They subsidize seated massages, yoga, and meditation classes, and provide tuition reimbursement.
The flexible work schedules and ability to work at home are great, too. If you are interested in the subject matter of psychology, it's the best place to work outside academia.
cons: There's been a lot of recent restructuring, which has made people feel insecure. The organization has been hit by the lackluster economy, so there's been some feeling of doom and gloom among some employees.

review_title: Easy, but everyone is very complacent.
pros: Easy going, flexible schedule, fun events, stress free. This is not a place you would hate coming to every day because of the culture or your co workers.
cons: Very little opportunity for growth, no professional development, very process oriented - process is sometimes put ahead of final goal, slow moving.

review_title: Great benefits, decent pay, bad managers. Definitely an "old boys club" mentality
pros: Very good benefits. Not the best ever, but better than average. Pay was decent, but not spectacular. Some mid and upper level managers were the best I ever had.
cons: Bottom line: if you're not a senior-level employee, you have no voice. If you are a senior-level employee, you can get away with murder and expect no consequences.

review_title: Great Benefits, Cool People, Changing with new leadership
pros: Generous benefits, PTO, 401k.  Really take care of the team.
cons: A lot of "this is how we do things" even though we're trying to change. Management really depends on which team you're part of. Can be really great or really hard depending on your group.  Not a lot of opportunities for career growth.  A place where a lot of people wait out the end of their careers.

pros: The ITS group is starting to bring in some exciting technology, especially in the area of publications.  There is great opportunity to learn new tools.  The people are great to work with
cons: Salaries are low and retention is difficult because of it.  Program and Project Management is non-existent and it is impossible to understand the workload by employee.  People work hard because they like the work, but rewards are scarce.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked
pros: flexible work schedule, friendly people, great benefits, inviting environment, excellent work/life balance
cons: salary may not be as high as FOR profit but I think they do a good job at being competitive with the market. There also a lot of bureaucracy to get stuff done and some people work really hard, while others just sit back and collect a pay check.

pros: Great work-life balance and benefits. My boss is the best boss I've ever had; however I can't vouch this to be true for every department. Most coworkers are professional, pleasant, and knowledgeable. Great mission to benefit society. Very liberal organization.
cons: Change can be difficult and slow; no opportunities for career growth; some managers are appointed based on their tenure regardless of skill; not enough training opportunities; low salary raises.

review_title: Company isn't what it used to be
pros: Good benefits, staff activities, central location to DC
cons: Lots of recent staff turnover and tension given the recent power shifts in the company. Many senior executive staff members are enforcing personal agendas and not having the entire organization as top priority. Mundane working loads and environments. Somewhat of a toxic work atmosphere.

pros: Very strong internship program, fostered mentorship, welcoming environment, encouraged direct participation with all related work
cons: Could be slow in the summer months, not consistent workflow for interns. Interns are exclusive to each department and don't get to learn much - hands on anyways - about the rest of the APA

pros: The benefits, the kindness and accommodation of the people, the work ethic - there's nothing NOT to love.
cons: Current self-evaluation backlash and layoffs have created an aura of poor staff morale. However, management and APA has been open and accommodating to all staff. Those who were laid off received substantial severance packages.

job_title: Applications Delivery Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Mental health benefits, cutting edge web development technology implementations, work life balance, telecommuting option, not for profit model, decent pay scales for skilled workers
cons: No growth, work overload, poor to no management within ITS, lack of soft or management skills, no quality control, no close involvement in operational IT

review_title: Low staff morale, unnecessary new positions, incompetent senior staff
pros: Central DC location, good benefits, gym, good work experience. Strong emphasis on work/life balance and stress-free workplace environment
cons: Incompetent senior lever staff which often creates toxic and dismal work environment. Lots of political and departmental battle and ego. Low ceiling for career growth and opportunity. Creation of unnecessary positions considering there are many staff members who are experienced and often underused and undervalued. Nepotism — senior level staff members who are creating positions to hire former colleagues and friends (i.e. Membership Recruitment and Engagement Department).

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Access to some of the best, niche psychological research and with some of the most admirable psychologists in the field
cons: Some of the employees were just so low-par. Hiring practices were not at all thorough. Position and job descriptions did not allow for taking initiative whatsoever. Consensus building culture led to too much inactivity.

pros: There are some really nice people working there. The only reason people stay so long are the awesome benefits and relationships with good people.
cons: It's hard to advance.  Management does not push growth.  And some managers seem not to care about opening doors for growth.

review_title: Run - do not walk away from this employer
pros: APA used to be a good organization with a strong mission. You would wake up thinking you were making a difference in the world.
cons:
Leadership does not care about anyone other than c-suite level input. They have forgotten the organization's mission which instilled values among staff and culture. 

The $12m budget deficit is just one warning across the bow of the sinking ship. 

As a 14+ year employee I do not see how this 125+ year old org will be standing in 10 years.  The day-to-day life-work balance was good, but beyond that there are few notables to celebrate. No raises in 2020. Historically, some staff get an annual "merit" increase that does not keep up with the cost of inflation. A 2% increase each year for 5 years puts you far behind. After a few years, you are making far less than someone with your same job in another nonprofit in Washington DC.  

There is no room for advancement. Internal applicants are told you can not receive over a 10% salary increase if you get a new position within APA. You must leave APA and come back to get a real raise. Yet, they will give an unknown new employee off the street the benefit of an increase for that postion over someone they know as a current employee.

review_title: Not much can go wrong when all of your bosses are clinical psychologists
pros: Managers are contientious, very thoughtful about the well-being of staff. My supervisor was very interested in my career goals and how to help me develop. I learned a lot from my supervisor. Work-life balance was an important issue that they reasonably try to accommodate. Very inclusive and diverse work environment.
cons: Pay can be lower than you expect because it is a nonprofit company.

pros: Great people and psychology focused with great perks and events to attend.
cons: Limited upward mobility; can be challenging if you are not in the field of psychology.

review_title: Stay away. Unless you have a PhD it's a sinkhole for career and salary.
pros: Convenient location. Some travel . Lots of time off.
cons: Anyone who isn't a psychologist is a second class citizen and can't have a thought or opinion.

pros: Great benefits, knowledgeable and supportive co workers, good location, takes staff health and wellness seriously, strong and caring members. Values employees.
cons: Experiencing difficult budget times and dipping moral. Leadership in turmoil and high turn over. Lack of transparency and regular communication.

review_title: Run, Do Not Walk from this place.
pros: Convenient location for mass transit and restaurants.
cons: Everything else. Stay well clear of the journals department; the current Journals Publisher isn't fit to run a flea circus, much less multi-million dollar journals program.

job_title: Manager, Service Center Operations in Washington, DC
pros: I've been with the APA for 13+ years. It's s decent company to work for. APA takes an in interest in its employees. It has a good benefit package; it welcomes opinions and ideas from employees; and has fair salary compensation. Does a good job of keeping employees apprised of what is going on in the company.
cons: Could probably do a better job sticking to it's own rules and regulations.

pros: Some great, very intelligent colleagues.
cons: The organization is foundering. Upper management has no vision to right the ship. Pay is substandard, particularly for the DMV area.  The organization is clinging to old styles of management and hierarchy.

pros: APA has a lot of programs for employee health - fitness class and facility, on-site upper body massage, health screening, mental health coverage, finance workshops and one-on-one consultation, trainings, etc.
cons: Limited career path, politics among different directorates, insufficient/ineffective communications, lack of clear directions

pros: nap room. close proximity to union station so there are good food options. depending on the position, work at home is available.
cons: management is ineffective. APA's business model is outdated. promotions all happen from within so there are a lot of people in upper management who are ineffective at their job. there are never any significant salary increases.

review_title: Good managers and culture but very little room for growth.
pros:
Managers and organization overall are loyal to employees.  
Organization takes the mission seriously.
Organization is very focused on creating a good culture.
Employees have opportunities to be involved in work outside their department.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement.  Expect to work there for years before your financial situation changes much.

pros: Staff have access to onsite massage, yoga, meditation, zumba and other exercise classes. Very low turnover -  staff who do leave often end up coming back.  Lots of new blood/ new energy on senior management group
cons: Recent budget cuts and management shake up created a lot of stress.  Because of low turnover, it is often difficult to move up.

pros: There are plenty of nice people that work here. Very flexible schedule available including telecommute option. Great Health Benefits.
cons: Low Salary, no upward mobility, seems like a dead end job if you're not on the executive track.

pros: They make a deliberate effort to promote employee wellness. The anonymous feedback system on the intranet is valuable for raising sensitive concerns.
cons: Nobody's concerns are discarded entirely, but there is very visible preference given to those with friends in upper management. Chronic budgetary issues requiring staff and benefit reductions undermined efforts at promoting employee wellness.

pros: Emphasis on health and wellness - on-site gym and classes, good work/life balance and flexibility, employees are valued.
cons: Personnel problems with upper level managers are not addressed, pay is low and noticeable turf wars within the organization.

review_title: Very positive experience; the company is centered around work-life balance.
pros: Work-Life balance; opportunity to work in different positions throughout company departments
cons: Like many companies creativity is not valued; I've had several experiences of sexism/sexist comments (with the same employee) but it is ignored by managers because he has been there a long time

pros: Great perks like lunchtime yoga and telework
cons: Big changes in upper management, layoffs of long time staff, some due to outsourcing

pros:
- Great environment to work 
- Healthy hours
- Opportunity to work from home
- Perks to earn cash (contests) 
- Open-minded colleagues
cons:
- Yearly evaluations to increase pay
- Gossips among "old" staff
- Hierarchical system among management staff

pros: Large company, because of the size there is lots of opportunity to move and perhaps advance within the organization. Good benefits.
cons: The size of the organization can make people territorial about what they do.  There can be a lot of inter/intra-department politics.

pros: Great benefits, flexible schedule, great work life balance
cons: Little growth from within, low yearly raises ( 1-3% per year), not enough diversity in management

pros: Exciting to be here. CEO is visionary and passionate. Staff are smart. Heading to an even brighter future.
cons: Some staff who aren't on board with all the changes should look for new jobs. They would be happier and so would we.

pros: Known for being great to its employees. Use of PTO is very flexible.
cons: Not really any options for upward mobility. Increases in pay are also pretty much next to nothing.

pros: Friendly environment; great benefits; commitment to employee wellness such as fitness classes, interest groups and lectures, and access to two gyms
cons: low pay; sometimes could be very dull and not much work to do; not much room for innovation, independence, or growth; difficult to move up without higher degree

pros: Excellent work-life balance. A family like environment
cons: Very slow growth. Some people unwilling to share knowledge of legacy systems

pros: APA is a great place to work overall. I work with some very hardworking people, the benefits are good, and they care about their employees.
cons: There seems to be a large salary gap between entry-level positions and managers with few in-between opportunities.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Great culture, supportive staff , value work life balance. I found the work I did to be very interesting and engaging. I never really dreaded coming to work at all.
cons: The usuals that come with non-profits. Salary and benefits could be better.

pros: Flexible work environment, decent benefits.
cons: Job description does not match job - in the interview I was explicitly told my daily tasks would be wholly different from what I am actually asked to do... menial task after menial task.

pros: They care about their employees and provide a well rounded range of benefits.  There are also opportunities for advancement.
cons: Salaries are still within nonprofit ranges, although skewing higher as it is an association as opposed to an advocacy based NGO.

pros: Nice people. Good work life balance. Good cause. Successful organization. Financially stable.
cons: Very hierarchical. Office lighting was kind of depressing. Kind of academic and slow  to change be modern in some departments. A lot of micromanaging.

pros: Benefits, work-life balance, location, office space
cons: Psychologists without management knowledge or experience are in charge. No attention paid to basic Management 101 principles. Very heirarchical and old school. Out of touch with newer ways of doing business.

review_title: Make tough decisions during tough times
pros: Time off, interesting subject matter, good benefits
cons: Poor internal processes, lack of professional advancement and training, weak management

pros:
Theres free food and snacks
No stress
Health/self care is promoted 
Great pay
Nice people
cons: None..this was thee best job i had so far...i was apart of the rif due to Covid-19

review_title: Wouldn't recommend to friends and family
pros:
Great Work life balance
Lots of professional development opportunities available to those who are early in their career.
cons:
Lack of management accountability
Low pay for most employees
Lack of job growth

pros: Very good benefits to include many exercise classes for only $1.00 for an hour long class.
cons: minimum or no room for growth in finance management

review_title: The Golden Years are gone, slow decline
pros: Good work-life balance, exercise/stress-mediation classes, Benefits are good.
cons: No room for growth. High turnover ratios. Rapid change. Lack of organizational leadership. No pay raise in two years.

pros: Interesting work. Mostly good people. A lot better than other places.
cons: More opportunities for promotion or cost of living raises.

pros: Employee appreciation is widespread, benefits are excellent, pay is decent, opportunity for advancement and professional development is also widespread
cons: At times, leadership can be less than ideally responsive to employees

review_title: Very mundane and slow paced environment
pros: The office culture and relationship with staff and peers was extremely beneficial. Great overall work atmosphere.
cons: The amount of work and ability to move up was very limited, including personal growth.

job_title: Director Institutional Giving in Washington, DC
pros: pay, location, colleagues, benefits, office
cons: The foundation is part of the larger association, but gets little attention or funding

pros: Good benefits, employee programs, federal holidays, on-site gym, easy to balance work/life commitments
cons: Lower salaries, require more advanced degrees for most positions that make salaries that can sustain you

review_title: I liked the people but found opportunity for advancement lacking
pros: Beautiful building, nice people, good cause and mission
cons: I worked there during a period of change and leadership was lacking

pros: friendly work environment, extracurricular activities, wellness initiatives, volunteer opportunities
cons: extremely low pay esp for Washington DC,  few chances for upward mobility, inadequate prof development training

pros:
Great benefits
Flex work sched
Great mission
Varied activities
cons:
Slow to accept new ideas and create action
Certain directorates function via hierarchical management style

job_title: Technical Information Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits, culture, location, and salary are decent
cons: Opportunities to advance your career aren't available

pros: Employee recognition, small events with food, friendly people.
cons: Slow movement, seniority matters, it's a bit like the government in that timing and connections means a lot.

review_title: Incompetent Management, but a nice place
pros: great location, good office space
cons: poor communication, management was incompetent

pros: Their pay is quite low, no 401/403 retirement plan. .
cons: They have pension plan, but you could only vest 30% of it after working 3 years

pros: Very good benefits, very humane leadership that always looks out for employees
cons: Commute to downtown DC; headquarters is next to Union Station

pros: Great benefits, happy work environment, great people
cons: Bureaucracy can be frustrating; pay levels can be lower than average.

pros:
Respectful people
Good moral 
Stress free rooms, always staff initiatives
cons:
Low pay and no room for growth 
Gloomy work atmosphere, old building

job_title: "Senior Consultant, Data & Analytics, Data Management, and ML & AI" in Washington, DC
pros: Good work/life balance and flex schedules available. Also, wonderful people work here!
cons: Not much opportunity for advancement within the organization.

pros: Benefits, fitness, flexibility, colleagues, learning experiences
cons: The pay could be a little higher given the area.

job_title: Manager, Electronic Product Support in Washington, DC
pros: Title is being removed from APA venue as of Dec 1, 2015
cons: Job is has been lost to reorganization effort.

review_title: Almost two years at the APA
job_title: Editorial Manuscript Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: Awesome connections in the publishing industry and academia.
cons: High turnover in the lower ranks of employees; employee/upper management disconnect.

pros: Amazing benefits/employee engagement activities and initiatives
cons: Some senior staff slightly unwilling to embrace new ideas

review_title: Great environment to work in. They have a diverse approach to mental health!
pros:
Passionate people 
Great location
casual atmosphere
cons: Not much growth within org

pros: Have been working for APA for years.  Good growth potential and opportunity. Large patient base
cons: always very active and busy

job_title: Web Content Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Nice people, interesting material
cons: Didn’t get a lot of direction

pros: Tuition reimbursement and paid all federal holidays
cons: Low job security and manager at the time did not know the work.

pros: Great benefits and people to work with
cons: Not enough opportunities to grow internally

pros: Company is very family oriented
cons: Senior level management needs to be more aware of company policies and procedures.

pros: Great people who care. Nice benefits package.
cons: ZERO opportunity for advancement. Salary is awful.

pros: Awesome staff to work with at this place of employment
cons: There really are no cons at this place of employment

pros: I enjoyed my time there.
cons: Lip service about progressive values but actions speak louder than words.

pros:
- Everyone is nice
- Easy going
- Flexible
cons:
- Not much thing to do
- Slow pace

pros: decent benefits, working towards a good cause
cons: disorganized, long hours, weak matrix type organization

pros: pay is entirely too low for the duties of the position
cons: there is a great community of people

pros: This place offers great benefits.
cons: This place has poor communication between departments

pros: Great Co-workers, Good resources, Decent Benefits
cons: Management issues, Hierarchy based, Chaotic at times

pros: Great people and friendly environment.
cons: I wish to remain anonymous.

pros: Great working form home options would recommend
cons: Bad bonus structure for long term employees

job_title: Senior Web Developer in Washington, DC
pros: Nice management, diversity, value the employee
cons: Salaries below the market, no bounce

pros: good environment and great people
cons: long days and long weeks

pros: Great place to work at, flexible schedule.
cons: Budget cut, creating job cuts

pros: Good opportunities for advancement
cons: Managers dont communicate to staff

pros: Informative, people were friendly and helpful
cons: Office environment is drab

pros: One, location by the train station so easy commute.
cons: No upward mobility.  Low pay.

review_title: No what it used to be
pros: Work-life balance, benefits, work training
cons: Bad management, low morale, low pay, fraternity-like atmosphere
